s.text: "His success depends on the extent to which he can assimilate into the political life of the country groups that until now have been opposed to its institutions," it concluded.
"His success depends on the extent to which he can assimilate into the political life of the country groups that until now have been opposed to its institutions," it concluded.

However, the stability of a pegged rate would come at the cost of Canadian independence: "By adopting a fixed exchange rate, Canada would essentially cede control over monetary policy to the United States Federal Reserve Board, yielding one more lever of economic policy to international forces."
In an editorial Monday, the paper opines, "Revenge is a dish that shouldn't be eaten at all; certainly not by a state.
